description: Easy - Context and Background: Remaining Peoples and Pyrrhus

questions.question: What was Rome's military and political situation immediately after the Samnite Wars ended in 290 BCE?
options: Rome controlled only the central Italian peninsula with no remaining independent rivals
Rome had conquered the entire Italian peninsula and stood completely unchallenged
Rome was weakened and vulnerable to invasion from external Mediterranean powers
Rome dominated much of Italy but still faced independent peoples and Greek city-states

questions.question: Which Greek city in southern Italy was the largest and most powerful, controlling major naval and commercial power?
options: Naples, which dominated southern Italian coastal trade and commerce
Syracuse, which was located in Sicily and controlled Mediterranean trade routes
Tarentum, which was built on an excellent harbor and was a major naval power
Rhegium, which controlled the southern approach to mainland Italian territories
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Tarentum and the Greek Threat

questions.question: What regions of Italy remained partially independent or outside direct Roman control after the Samnite Wars?
options: Only Etruria in the north remained independent while all southern regions submitted
Southern Italy, Greek cities, Lucania, Bruttium, and parts of Etruria remained outside Roman control
Only the island of Sicily remained independent while all mainland Italy was conquered
The entire Italian peninsula was completely unified under direct Roman administrative control

questions.question: Who was King Pyrrhus and from which kingdom did he rule?
options: A Macedonian king who controlled all of Greece and the Balkan peninsula regions
King of Epirus, a Hellenistic kingdom in northwestern Greece related to Alexander the Great
A Syrian king from the Seleucid empire who ruled Asian Mediterranean territories
The king of Egypt who controlled North African and Mediterranean commercial power

questions.question: What military experience and background did Pyrrhus have before his invasion of Italy?
options: He had only ruled his small kingdom and had no previous military experience
He served various rulers in the Near East and learned Hellenistic military tactics
He conquered most of Greece and Egypt before attempting to invade Italy
He had studied under Alexander the Great and served as his personal military commander
questions.text_reference: Section 4: Background and Rise to Power

questions.question: Why did Tarentum appeal to King Pyrrhus for military assistance against Rome?
options: Tarentum wanted to expand its empire throughout the entire Mediterranean region
Tarentum recognized Roman expansion southward as a threat to its independence and interests
Tarentum was threatened by other Italian peoples and needed any available military aid
Tarentum wanted to hire Pyrrhus as a military advisor for tactical training purposes
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Tarentum and the Greek Threat

questions.question: What motivated Pyrrhus to accept Tarentum's invitation to invade Italy?
options: He could gain wealth, military glory, and possibly establish a Mediterranean dominion
He wanted to help Greek cities and had no personal ambitions for power or wealth
He was fleeing threats to his kingdom and needed a temporary refuge in Italy
He wanted to unite all Greek peoples under his rule throughout the Mediterranean

questions.question: What military forces did Pyrrhus bring with him when he invaded Italy in 280 BCE?
options: Approximately ten thousand infantry soldiers with no cavalry or specialized weaponry
A hundred thousand soldiers from various allied Hellenistic kingdoms and regions
Only mercenary forces from Greece with no professional military organization
A well-equipped army including infantry, cavalry, and war elephants

questions.question: Why were war elephants considered the most advanced military technology of Pyrrhus's era?
options: They were used exclusively by Greek armies and no other power possessed them
They could carry large numbers of soldiers and operated as mobile fortresses
They were large, armored, trained for warfare, and completely unknown to Italian armies
They were primarily used for transportation rather than direct combat purposes

questions.question: What was Pyrrhus's strategic vision for Italy when he arrived to support Tarentum?
options: To provide limited military aid and then return immediately to his homeland
To establish himself as a dominant power, defeat Rome militarily, and create a lasting kingdom
To liberate all Italian peoples from Roman control and create a democratic federation
To conquer Sicily and use it as a base for Mediterranean commercial expansion
